abstract.para: This document describes the basic principles and usage of &ulp;.

sect1.title: About &ulp;
sect1.para: Userspace live patching (&ulpa;) refers to the process of applying patches to the libraries used by a running process, without interrupting it. Live patching operations are performed using the ulp tool that is part of the libpulp.
libpulp is a framework that enables &ulp;. It consists of the libpulp.so library and tools for making libraries live-patchable and applying live patches (the ulp binary).

sect2.title: Prerequisites
sect2.para: For &ulpa; to work, two requirements must be met.

listitem.para: To be live-patchable, a library must be compiled with the -fpatchable-function-entry GCC flag. No changes to the library source code are required.
Processes must preload the libpulp.so library.

sect2.title: Using libpulp
sect2.para: To use libpulp with an application, you must perform the following steps:

listitem.para: When launching the application, preload libpulp with the LD_PRELOAD=/usr/lib64/libpulp.so ./APPLICATION command.

sect3.title: Preparing a library to be live-patchable
sect3.para: For a library to be live-patchable, it must contain a NOP prologue in all function calls. GCC version 8 and higher, as well as the GCC version that ships with &sls;, provides the -fpatchable-function-entry specifically for that purpose. Thus on the &x86-64; architecture, compiling a library written in C with -fpatchable-function-entry=16,14 flag is sufficient to make it live-patchable.
The glibc, libssl.so.1.1, and libcrypto.so.1.1 libraries are already live-patchable on &sle; &product-ga; SP&product-sp;.

sect3.title: Checking if a library is live-patchable
sect3.para: To check whether a library is live-patchable, use the following script:
sect3.screen:
#!/bin/sh
is_lib_livepatcheable() { ULP_NOPS_LEN=16 ULP_PRE_NOPS_LEN=14 ULP_NOP_OPCODE=90
local lib_path=$1 local address_of_a_symbol=`objdump -T $lib_path | grep '\.text' | head -n 1 | awk '{ print $1 }'`
if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then echo "Unable to find a symbol in $lib_path" exit 1 fi
# Convert hexadecimal address in decimal so we can do mathematical operations local addr_decimal=`printf "%llu" "0x$address_of_a_symbol"` if [ $addr_decimal -eq 0 ]; then echo "Symbol at address found is invalid: $address_of_a_symbol" exit 1 fi
local ulp_prologue_dec=`expr $addr_decimal - $ULP_PRE_NOPS_LEN` local ulp_prologue_addr=`printf "0x%lx" $ulp_prologue_dec`
# Get bytes at target library. It should have $ULP_NOPS_LEN nops (0x90 on x86) local insns=`xxd -s $ulp_prologue_addr -l $ULP_PRE_NOPS_LEN -c $ULP_PRE_NOPS_LEN \ -g $ULP_PRE_NOPS_LEN $lib_path | grep -oEi "($ULP_NOP_OPCODE){$ULP_PRE_NOPS_LEN}"`
# If library is not live-patchable, insns is empty. if [ -z "$insns" ]; then return 1 fi
return 0 }
if [ -z $1 ]; then echo "usage: $0 <.so_to_check>" exit 1 fi
is_lib_livepatcheable $1 if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then echo "library $1 is not livepatchable: missing NOP prologue" else echo "library $1 is livepatchable" fi
